Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Stability and Reactivity of Radical Cations for Improved Overcharge Protection in Lithium-Ion Batteries
Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms - B Program of the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Susan A. Odom from the University of Kentucky will seek to improve the stability of radical cation forms of aromatic molecules used as redox shuttle electrolyte additives for overcharge protection in lithium-ion batteries. The lifetimes of the radical cations in a variety of solvent environments, including carbonates used as battery electrolytes will be characterized to determine decomposition products upon oxidation. Analysis of these products will determine (i) how solvent environment affects the reaction outcome, (ii) what features results in more stable radical cations, and (iii) if there is a correlation in radical cation persistence vs. the number of cycles overcharge protection in a lithium-ion battery before redox shuttle decomposition. Higher oxidation potential shuttles for new cathode materials will be synthesized and methods to stabilize the resulting radical cations, by surrounding them in protective cages and extending electronic delocalization, will be explored.

The results of this research project have potential to provide benefits to the scientific community and our society in the development of new materials for the improved performance and safety of energy storage materials, specifically lithium-ion batteries. As the number of hybrid electric vehicles and the need for storage of renewable energy sources continue to grow, it becomes more important to have reliable energy storage. Electrolyte additives that improve the safety and lifetimes of lithium-ion batteries are needed to expedite the growth of this technology for use in multiple applications. This project will expose students at different levels (high school, undergraduate, and graduate students) to scientific research, in a growing area of social and practical importance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the design and synthesis of new organic materials as additives for lithium-ion batteries. The additives type studied here, called redox shuttles, protect batteries during overcharge by limiting cell voltage. Through the structure/property relationships of various additive molecules, information was gained about their stability and reactivity. Further structural modification enabled the design of improved derivatives with more robust characteristics, resulting in overcharge protection that is among the most extensive reported to date. If incorporated into commercial lithium-ion cells, resultant lithium-ion batteries would be safer because their likelihood of entering dangerous thermal runaway would be internally mitigated. The results led to numerous peer-reviewed publications and patent applications on redox shuttles and their properties in cycling batteries. Some of these materials are now being evaluated as active components in non-aqueous redox flow batteries, which are of interest for large-scale grid storage. Materials in both states of oxidation of a redox couple have been isolated as crystalline materials, highlighting the incredible stability of the derivatives. The core structure, phenothiazine, was once produced on large scales as an herbicide, making it a potentially useful starting material for the cost-effective production of large quantities of materials. Support from this project allowed for the training of undergraduate and graduate students as well as extensive outreach activities. Odom participated in many educational activities with students and the general public including interactive Molecular Gastronomy experiments. She co-organized an interactive presentation on science and chemistry called Looking for Light. She also co-organized the first Expanding Your Horizons Conference at the University of Kentucky where about 150 middle school girls attended inquiry based workshops led by undergraduate and graduate students who were trained in an Experiential Education course at UK.
